children.name: recruit
children.definition: /rɪˈkruːt/  to find new people to work for a company.
examples: tuyển dụng
It’s getting more and more difficult to recruit experienced staff.
We’re not recruiting at the moment.
recruit[C noun] [C2] someone who has been recruited recently: người được chiêu mộ
Peter is one of our new recruits.

children.name: fill
children.definition: verbJOB bổ nhiệm làm đầy;chứa đầy;đổ đầy
examples: [ T ] to givea job or positionto someone
_I'm sorry, thejob/post/vacancyhas already been filled.
_We would prefer to fill the postwith(= give it to) a recent graduate.

children.name: when there are not enough people working in a company etc
be understaffed
children.definition: a company or organization thatis understaffeddoes not have enough people working in it because itcannotorwillnotemploy more people:
examples: ▪ It’s crazy that unemployment is sky-high while so many companies are still understaffed.
▪ The few public health clinics that existed were filthy and understaffed.

children.name: be short-staffed
children.definition: especially British alsobe short-handedespecially American /biː ˌʃɔːʳt ˈstɑːftǁ-ˈstæft, biː ˌʃɔːʳt ˈhændd/  to not have the number of people you need to do a job properly or on time, especially because some of the people who usually work are ill, on holiday etc:
examples: thiếu nhân sự
▪ Schools in inner city areas are often short-staffed because the work is particularly stressful.
▪ After three hours, Mrs Morrison was told that her operation had been cancelled because the hospital was short-staffed.
▪ Let me know if you’re short-handed -- I’ll get a couple of the boys to help out.

children.name: vacant
children.definition: /ˈveɪkənt/  not being done by anyone at the moment and therefore available:
examples: bỏ trống
▪ Our company only has one or two vacant positions at the moment.
Hiện giờ công ty tôi chỉ có một hoặc hai vị trí trống thôi
▪ When the post became vacant it was offered to Wendy Brooks.
Khi càng trở nên trống trải, nó được bán cho Wendy Brooks
fall vacant become vacant British
▪ He applied for the job of Eliot’s personal secretary, which had just fallen vacant.
Anh ta đã nộp đơn xin làm thư ký cá nhân của Eliot khi vị trí đó vừa mới trống

children.name: vacancy
children.definition: an available job
examples: ▪ There are over 3 million people unemployed and only 400,000 vacancies.
▪ I’m sorry, the firm has no vacancies at the moment.
fill a vacancy
▪ Barnhart will fill a vacancy on the Planning Commission

children.name: open
children.definition: trống
examples: open/ˈəʊpən/ [adjective not before noun] a job that is open, especially a job that needs a lot ofskill, is still available because it has not yet been given to anyone else:
▪ Is that job you told me about last week still open?
open to
▪ The position is open to graduates in any subject.
come open
▪ When the job finally came open, I was the first to apply.
Khi vị trí này trống, tôi là người đầu tiên nộp đơn

children.name: opening
children.definition: công việc , vị trí trống
examples: opening/ˈəʊpənɪŋ/ [countable noun] an available job:
▪ I was wondering if there were any job openings at your company.
fill an opening
▪ We expect to fill most of the openings through internal promotion.

children.name: unfilled
children.definition: /ˌʌnˈfɪld◂/  a job or position that is unfilled is available because an employer has not yet decided who should do it, or cannot find someone suitable for it:
examples: ▪ About 13,000 of the unfilled positions are for software engineers.
▪ It’s hard to understand the unemployment figures when so many jobs go unfilled.

children.name: headhunt
children.definition: verb săn tuyển
examples: to persuade someone to leave their job by offering them another job with more pay and ahigher position
_She was headhunted by a rival firm.

children.name: headhunter
children.definition: nounJOB
examples: người có nhiệm vụ tìm và thu dụng những nhân viên giỏi; chuyên gia săn đầu người
a person who tries to persuade someone to leave their job by offering them anotherjob with more pay and a higher position

children.name: pursue
children.definition: verbTRY TO GET săn đuổi
examples: to try very hard to persuade someone to accept a job
_The company has been pursuing Holton for some time, but so far he has rejected all their offers.

children.name: give sb a job
children.definition: give somebody a job/ˌgɪv somebody ə ˈdʒɒbǁ-ˈdʒɑːb/
examples: ▪ If I give you the job, how soon can you begin?
▪ After law school, he was given a job in the city’s legal department.
give sb a job as
▪ Goldman gave her a job as his assistant.

children.name: employ / hire
children.definition: employalsohireespecially American /ɪmˈplɔɪ, haɪəʳ/  to give someone a job and pay them for the work they do for you:
examples: ▪ Since he came out of prison no one will employ him.
▪ The company has been accused of not hiring enough women.
employ as
▪ I was employed as a night-watchman by the local hospital.
▪ She was hired as marketing director for a biotechnology firm.

children.name: take on
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ˈɒn/  if a company takes on someone, it gives them a job - use this especially about a job that mightnot be permanentor whena lot of peopleare given jobs at the same time:
examples: take on somebody
▪ We’re not taking on any more staff at the moment.
take somebody etc on
▪ Franklin needed an assistant, and he got funding from the department to take one on.
take somebody on as something
▪ The director took me on as a messenger while they were filming in my village.

children.name: engage
children.definition: /ɪnˈgeɪdʒ/  Britishformalto give someone a job:
examples: ▪ The vet was increasingly busy and had to engage two new assistants.
engage somebody as something
▪ Paul was engaged as a junior clerk at a very low wage.

children.name: sign up
children.definition: alsosignAmerican /ˌsaɪn ˈʌp, saɪn/  if a football team, record company, film company etc signs up or signs someone, they agree to give them a job and make them sign anofficialcontract:
examples: ▪ Allegre was signed by the New York Jets.
▪ Six episodes of the show have been taped, and the actors have been signed for six more.
sign up somebody
▪ England soccer star Paul Gascoigne was signed up by a top Italian club.
sign somebody up
▪ The band have just completed a highly successful US tour, and several record companies have offered to sign them up.

children.name: outsource
children.definition: verb thuê ngoài gia công
examples: If a company outsources, it pays to have part of its work done by another company
_Unions are fighting a plan by universities to outsource all non-academic services.
_Some companies outsource to cheaper locations to cut costs.

outsourcingnoun[ U ] sự gia công; sự thực hiện dịch vụ bằng nguồn lực bên ngoài; sự đồng ý nhận linh kiện, phụ tùng do một nhà cung cấp khác hoặc một nhà sản xuất khác cung ứng và như vậy đỡ tốn kém hơn là mình tự làm lấy
_The management guaranteed that outsourcing wouldn't mean job losses.

children.name: recruitment
children.definition: noun sựtuyển dụng;
examples: the process of finding people to work for a company or become a new member of anorganization
_The recession has forced a lot of companies to cut down on graduate recruitment.
_It's all part of a recruitmentdriveintended to increase the party's falling numbers.

children.name: recruit
children.definition: someone who has been recruited:
examples: ▪ At many banks, young recruits first work as tellers.

children.name: shortlist
children.definition: UK,USshort listnoun danh sách sơ tuyển (trước khi tuyển chọn chung cuộc)
examples: a list of people who have been judged the most suitable for a job or prize, made froma longer list of people originally considered, and from which one person will be chosen
_We'vedrawn up(= decided) a shortlist for the job.
_She'sonthe shortlist for a teaching post.

children.name: employment
children.definition: / hiring
examples: ▪ This letter outlines the terms and conditions of employment the conditions of your job.

children.name: employment
children.definition: /ɪmˈplɔɪmənt/  when people work or have jobs - used especially inofficialdocuments, news reports etc :
examples: ▪ I have not yet signed a contract of employment.
▪ A Japanese company plans to set up a factory in the area, so this should provide some employment for local people.
be in employmenthave a job
▪ Are you in full-time employment, Mr Edwards?
employment[uncountable noun]
▪ This letter outlines the terms and conditions of employment the conditions of your job.

children.name: vacancy
children.definition: /ˈveɪkənsi/  a job that is available, and that someone could start doing immediately :
examples: chỗ trống, công việc trống
▪ There might be some vacancies at the hospital.
vacancy for
▪ A vacancy exists for an import/export sales manager at our Paris office.
fill a vacancy :find someone to do the job :
lấp chỗ trống , công việc trống
▪ Skilled workers are few, and employers are having trouble filling vacancies.

children.name: opening
children.definition: /ˈəʊpənɪŋ/  a job that is available - used especiallybymanagersor bypeople asking about jobs:
examples: chỗ trống, công việc trống ( từ dùng bởi quản lý hay người xin việc)
▪ Of the fourteen openings, only one went to a minority candidate.
opening for
▪ I was wondering if you had any openings for sales staff?
job openings
▪ The journal has been a good way to publicize job openings.

children.name: opportunity
children.definition: /ˌɒpəˈtjuːnɪti, ˌɒpəˈtjuːnətiǁˌɑːpərˈtuː-/  the chance to do a job that you want to do, which could lead to a good permanent job:
examples: opportunity for
▪ There are several opportunities for experienced designers and researchers.
career opportunities : cơ hội việc làm
▪ Career opportunities for nurses have improved in the last 10 years.
